posts.cooked: My team runs a modified AndyMark Climber in a Box as a linear extender for our telescopic arm. A NEO motor powers extending and retracting. As the arm is powered by a rope, powering the motor after it extends fully causes it to wind the other direction and retract again. What is the best method of measuring how much the arm is extended? Would using the built-in encoder be sufficient?

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
You can use the built-in encoder for this purpose, however that encoder only gives a relative output, meaning the encoder position resets to 0 every time it is restarted/power cycled. so unless you ensure the starting position when you power on the robot is identical every time, the values would be different each time.

A way to mitigate this is by using a limit switch to move the extension to a known position, and then resetting the encoder so the values should stay consistent. This approach is what 3468 did last year for our climber. At the start of the match (or with the press of a button) we would run the climber arms down until they hit the limit switches, then reset the encoders and go to our ‚Äústowed‚Äù position, and at the end of the match press a button to go to our ‚Äúextended‚Äù height.

One additional thing I will note, there will be some margin of error/slop in your values because the exact position of the arm relative to the number of rotations of the motor will vary a bit depending on how the rope spools/unspools over time.

We have CANcoders for absolute position as well. My main question is about taking the multiple rotations - do we have to manually count the number of rotations that are made to reach the appropriate position? What limit switch did you use?

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
IIRC you can have the encoder objects in WPILIB/RevLib/Phoenix track multiple rotations automatically with the absolute output, though you‚Äôd still need some kind of initialization with a limit switch or something since absolute encoders like the CANcoder, SRX Mag Encoder, or MA3 Encoder won‚Äôt track a multiple revolution position across re-boots either, making them little more valuable to you than any other encoder.

If you wanted to avoid limit switches, depending on how many revolutions you need to track, a 10-turn potentiometer as an absolute analog input would do the job since it tracks an absolute position across the 10 turns.

These are the switches 3468 used last year:

HiLetgo 3pcs ME-8108 Momentary Limit Switch Roller Lever CNC Mill Laser Plasma: Amazon.com: Industrial & Scientific

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
Here is the best picture I could find of the limit switches from last year‚Äôs bot. You can‚Äôt really see it in well in the picture but there is a plate attached to the bottom of the claw‚Äôs bracket that sticks out to make more consistent contact with the switch. There is also a similar switch on the other arm behind it that is just hidden by the front arm. image 715√ó806 61.6 KB

image 715√ó806 61.6 KB

image 715√ó806 61.6 KB

Thank you! We have had some limit switches from the FIRST Choice list (802K-MSRS11E + 889N-F5AE-6F); however, I‚Äôve found very little documentation of how they are used so I‚Äôd appreciate any help you could send my way.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
IDK anything about those specifically, but there should be either some wires on a pre-installed wire ‚Äúpig tail‚Äù or somewhere where you can attach some wires. Between two of the wires there will not be a connection until the limit switch is pressed, between another two of the wires they will always be connected unless the limit switch is pressed. The former is called NO (Normally Open) and the later NC (Normally Closed). Generally there will be three or four wires, in the case of three, one of them is the ‚ÄúCommon‚Äù between the NO and NC conacts.

The most common setup I see (there are advantages and disadvantages for using either NO or NC which you can likely find on other threads about Limit Switches here on CD) is you take the two wires for the NO connection and wire one to GND/+0V and the other to the Limit Switch input of a Motor Controller, or the Signal In of a DIO port on the RIO.

Then you just need the code to use it, either configuring the motor controller to use it or the RoboRIO to use it.

Sorry I am not providing more detailed information rn, but I am currently rushing to finish packing to head out for 3468‚Äôs first Regional of the season.
